Introduction

Cryoglobulins are abnormal immunoglobulins that characteristically precipitate at temperatures below 37 C (98.6 F) and dissolve on rewarming.  The presence of these immunoglobulins in the serum is referred to as cryoglobulinemia.  Cryoglobulins can form immune complexes (ICs) that deposit within small- to medium-sized blood vessels, triggering inflammation and tissue damage (ie, cryoglobulinemic vasculitis).  In addition, cryoglobulins can increase serum viscosity, leading to mechanical occlusion of the microcirculation.

Classification



Cryoglobulinemia is classified into 3 types based on immunoglobulin composition:



  • Type I:  Single monoclonal immunoglobulin (IgM or IgG), usually associated with lymphoproliferative disorders (eg, multiple myeloma, WaldenstrÃ¶m macroglobulinemia).
  • Type II:  Mixed cryoglobulins comprising monoclonal IgM with rheumatoid factor (RF) activity and polyclonal IgG; strongly linked to chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection.
  • Type III:  Mixed polyclonal IgM and IgG, typically associated with autoimmune diseases (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, SjÃ¶gren syndrome) or chronic infections.


Types II and III collectively account for approximately 80%-90% of symptomatic cases and are clinically grouped as mixed cryoglobulinemias (causing mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome [MCS]).

Pathophysiology



Cryoglobulinemia develops from immunoglobulins that reversibly precipitate at lower temperatures (<37 C [98.6 F]).  These immunoglobulins can form insoluble ICs (types II and III) or increase serum viscosity (type I).

Types II and II (mixed cryoglobulinemia)



Type II and III cryoglobulins, formed as a result of B-cell hyperactivation, lead to IgM binding to the Fc region of IgG (rheumatoid factor [RF] activity).  IgM-IgG complexes form ICs that deposit within small- and medium-sized vessels.  This activates the complement system, primarily via the classical pathway, resulting in inflammation (ie, vasculitis) and tissue injury.  Complement consumption leads to decreased serum complement (particularly C4).

Type I



Type I cryoglobulins, which are monoclonal immunoglobulins (IgM or IgG) produced in lymphoproliferative disorders, increase serum viscosity without forming ICs.  Hyperviscosity primarily impairs microcirculation mechanically, resulting in noninflammatory microvascular occlusion and ischemic organ damage.  Because complement is not consumed, serum levels are typically normal.

Clinical manifestations



Symptoms vary by subtype and the affected organs:

Skin



Cutaneous involvement occurs early in all symptomatic cases, often preceding extracutaneous manifestations by years.  Manifestations are largely dependent on cryoglobulin type:



  • Types II and III (mixed):  Erythematous macules and purpuric papules, typically in the lower extremities (ie, palpable purpura (
    image 1
    )).
  • Type I:  Raynaud phenomenon (
    image 2
    ), retiform purpura ("net-like" reflecting vascular architecture), and livedo reticularis (
    image 3
    ).  Infarction with ulceration and digital ischemia with gangrene can occasionally occur, particularly in the setting of hyperviscosity.

Musculoskeletal



Arthralgia and myalgia are common in MCS, particularly in the knees, ankles, and hands.  Frank arthritis is rare.

Renal



Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (discussed in a separate article) is seen in roughly 20% of cases of MCS, presenting with proteinuria, glomerular hematuria, and acute kidney injury.

Neurologic



Neurologic involvement is dependent on cryoglobulin type:



  • Types II and III:  Peripheral neuropathy, predominantly sensory due to vasculitic nerve damage.  CNS involvement is rare.
  • Type I:  CNS symptoms (eg, blurred vision, ataxia, vertigo) related to hyperviscosity (ie, impaired microcirculation).

Other organ involvement



Less common manifestations include pulmonary involvement (eg, impaired gas exchange, cough, pleurisy), lymphadenopathy, abdominal pain, and hepatomegaly with abnormal liver function tests.

Diagnosis



Cryoglobulinemia should be suspected in patients with symptoms consistent with vasculitis (types II and III) or hyperviscosity (type I).  Diagnostic evaluation includes:



  • Cryoglobulin testing:  Definitive diagnosis involves collecting blood samples, maintaining warmth during transport, and cooling plasma below 37 C (98.6 F) to precipitate cryoglobulins.  Quantification of cryoglobulins is measured using cryocrit testing.
  • Serum complement:  Low serum complement levels (particularly C4) are typical in MCS.  In type I cryoglobulinemia, complement levels are normal.
  • RF levels:  RF levels are frequently elevated in MCS and support the diagnostic finding.
  • Etiologic assessment:  Screening for underlying conditions is crucial, including testing for HCV, HIV, lymphoproliferative disorders, and autoimmune diseases.
  • Biopsy:  Biopsy of affected organs (eg, skin, kidneys) is often unnecessary for diagnosis but can confirm leukocytoclastic vasculitis and IC deposition.

Management



Treatment focuses on the underlying cause, reducing inflammation, and avoiding cold exposure.

 Type I



Management involves addressing the underlying lymphoproliferative disorder (eg, rituximab, bortezomib).  Patients with severe hyperviscosity syndrome should undergo plasmapheresis to remove circulating cryoglobulins.

Types II and III



Treatment includes stabilizing end-organ damage (eg, glomerulonephritis) using rituximab plus prednisone.  In addition, the underlying trigger (eg, antiviral therapy for HCV infection) should be addressed.  In life-threatening cases (eg, pulmonary hemorrhage, renal failure requiring hemodialysis), plasmapheresis is typically used as adjunctive therapy.

Summary



Cryoglobulinemia (

) is a vasculitic condition driven by cold-sensitive immunoglobulins and is classified into subtypes based on distinct immunologic mechanisms.  Types II and III (mixed cryoglobulinemia) are frequently linked to chronic infections (eg, hepatitis C) and autoimmune diseases, typically presenting with palpable purpura, arthralgia, and glomerulonephritis; pathophysiology involves immune complex formation leading to inflammatory vasculitis.  Type I cryoglobulinemia is far less common and is associated primarily with lymphoproliferative disorders, presenting with microvascular occlusion causing hyperviscosity-related manifestations (eg, digital ischemia, CNS involvement).  Diagnosis relies on detecting cryoglobulins (present in all types) and complement levels (decreased in types II and III).  Management targets underlying causes and inflammation control, with the prognosis varying significantly according to subtype and treatment responsiveness.
